titleStmt.title: Globalization and the Retreat of Citizen Participation in Collective Action: A Challenge for Public Administration

affiliation.orgName: Division of Public Administration and Policy

analytic.title: Globalization and the Retreat of Citizen Participation in Collective Action: A Challenge for Public Administration

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Abstract: Globalization challenges the ability of contemporary public administration to encourage citizen participation in collective action through behaviors such as tax compliance and contributions to public goods.

The authors introduce a new individual-level approach to globalization, arguing that people vary in the extent to which they are globalized and that an individual's level of globalism (ILG) reflects attitudes and dispositions that influence the way he or she resolves the social dilemma of participation in collective action (i.e., the decision to contribute versus follow a "free-ride" strategy).
Using a four-country sample, the article examines the relationship between ILG and collective action participation decisions in three behavioral experiments.

Findings support the hypothesis that regardless of country-level globalization, a more globalized individual complies less willingly with tax codes, donates less to local nongovernmental organizations, and prefers to adopt a free-ride strategy in a public goods game.
The consequences for public administration are discussed.

div.head: Practitioner Points

p.s: • Globalization has made the citizen-government relationship more bilateral, changing the status of citizens from a "captive audience" of the local public administration to active "customers" who subscribe to "place polygamy" and are prepared to exercise their "exit" option.

• Individuals who score higher on the globalism scale adopt a systematic behavior pattern in which they are significantly more likely to free-ride in public goods provision processes and significantly less likely to comply with tax laws or donate to local charities.
• Public administrators must understand who citizens are before they can understand the best way to govern.
• Our findings support concerns about the incapability of contemporary governments to "steer" their populations.
Globalization and the Retreat of Citizen Participation in Collective Action: A Challenge for Public Administration

div.note: Eitan Adres Dana R. Vashdi Yair Zalmanovitch

p.s: University of Haifa, Israel G lobalization has added layers of complexity with respect to how public interest is defined and manifested" (Koppell 2015, 56).

This complexity poses new challenges to public administration and a general governability crisis as it is causing radical changes in public administration's character and the behavior of citizens and a decline in authority and legitimacy (Cheung 2009;Farazmand 2001Farazmand , 2009)).
As Farazmand (2001) put it, "the nature of the state, government, and public administration has changed, with significant implications for governance and self-determination worldwide."

Globalization has made the citizen-government relationship more bilateral, changing the status of citizens from a "captive audience" of the local public administration to active "customers" who subscribe to "place polygamy" (Beck 2000) and are prepared to exercise their "exit" option (Hirschman 1970).

These shifts have taken place against a backdrop of growing discontent with the market model of New Public Management, which seems to hinder a return to substantive democracy, and of rekindled public discourse about the value-based model of New Public Service, the purpose of collective action, and the meaning of concepts such as "publicness," "citizen participation," "democratic values," and "creating public value" (Box et al. 2001;Denhardt and Denhardt 2015;Haque 2001;Roberts 2004).
In this article, we posit that globalization challenges the ability of contemporary public administration to encourage citizen participation in collective action (such as paying taxes).

We examine our hypotheses in an experimental, four-country comparative project that addresses the social dilemma of contributions to public goods, which are the main outcome of collective action, in light of the contemporary phenomenon of globalization.

Following public choice theory, which considers the individual, or "the decision maker," as the basic unit of analysis and conceptualizes public goods as the output of public administration " (Ostrom and Ostrom 1971), we investigate this relationship at the individual level using the individual's level of globalism (ILG) scale (see the supplementary material available in the online version of this article).
ILG enables us to assess the consequences of a more "globalized" outlook on the tendency of individuals to contribute to local public goods.

In addition, as collective action is "the core of the justification for the state" (Ostrom 1998, 1), we address one possible facet of Ostrom's concern that "[a]s global relationships become even more intricately intertwined and complex, however, our survival becomes more dependent on empirically grounded scientific understanding.

We have not yet developed a behavioral theory of collective action based on models of the individual consistent with empirical evidence about how individuals make decisions in socialdilemma situations" (1998,1).

Groups of individuals (a state in our case) with common interests and goals often attempt to further those common interests through actions taken together (i.e., collective action; see Moore 2014;Olson 1971, 1).

Public goods, which are the yields of collective action, include the most fundamental services provided by a nation-state, such as national defense, police protection, and the judicial system, as well as environmental protections, human and civil rights, public roads, and public radio and television.

Public goods are characterized as nonrivalrous, meaning that their use or consumption by one individual does not reduce their availability to others, and as nonexcludable, meaning that if they are available to anyone, they must be available to all (Olson 1971, 14).

In order to obtain the resources needed for the provision of public goods and services, "democratic governments are able to elicit, legally and legitimately, both money and men from their populations" (Levi 1997, 1-2).
The provision of public goods and services inherently entails the restriction of individual and economic freedoms (Olson 1971, 95).
These governmental demands evoke a social dilemma whereby "individuals . . .
face choices in which the maximization of shortterm self-interest yields outcomes leaving all participants worse off than feasible alternatives" (Ostrom 1998, 1).

In other words, given the nonexcludability principle, from a purely rational point of view, individuals should respond to demands for contributions to public goods by "free-riding," for example, through tax evasion, draft evasion, and other forms of disobedience.
Despite the existence of such rational free-ride solutions, many citizens willingly consent to these demands, well beyond the extent explicable by effective coercion (Levi 1997, 2).
In addition, much room exists in liberal democratic societies for individuals to produce "public value" through the provision of public goods such as charity and voluntary civic action (Moore 2014).
Over the years, an extensive literature has sought to explain the motivations behind individual contributions to public goods despite the free-ride option (Olson 1971).

It has been suggested that over and above institutional means (i.e., coercion), the way in which citizens resolve the social dilemma of participation in collective action reflects their relationships with society and the state, as well as individual predispositions formed by values, identities, traits, and capacities that may be affected by society's culture, values, and social norms (Chong 2000, 46).
These relationships with the state are bilateral.

Individuals seem to agree to contribute to public goods if the government providing the goods (and demanding the contributions) meets certain conditions, such as showing itself trustworthy (Levy 1997, 21-24).
However, we suggest that today, the likelihood of contributing to local public goods is also influenced by an additional process: globalization.
The term "globalization" has been defined in many ways.

However, almost all definitions involve the notion that globalization refers to the apparent "shrinking" of distances between different places as a result of the emergence and thickening of environmental, social, and economic networks (Guillen 2001;Keohane and Nye 2001;Scholte 2005).

This shrinkage results in enhanced interdependence and mutual awareness among social, economic, and political units around the world (Giddens 1999;Guillen 2001;Held and McGrew 2008;Scholte 2005Scholte , 2008)).
Advances in technology have helped produce this situation in different ways.

The increasing speed and affordability of long-distance travel have made long distances less meaningful both for individuals and for businesses, even as the exponential growth of electronic communications systems and devices (the Internet, social media, smartphones, global television, etc.) has created a new virtual and supraterritorial global reality that makes actual travel often unnecessary.

As a result, "people [have] become more able-physically, legally, linguistically, culturally and psychologically-to engage with each other wherever on earth they might be" (Scholte 2008(Scholte , 1478)).

Contemporary globalization and the linked concept of supraterritoriality have raised questions regarding the effects of enhanced interdependence among nations and the roles that institutions may play as this interdependence increases (Keohane 2001).

Research in political science, public administration, and sociology has explored the changing meanings of terms such as "national authority" and "national boundaries" in the context of globalization (Farazmand 1999(Farazmand , 2001;;Guillen 2001).

Some scholars believe that the traditional mode of governance in public administration, which was top-down and state-centric (Cheung 2009), is being replaced by a new "polycentric" model, with many centers of decision making that are formally independent of each other (Scholte 2005).

Either way, globalization undermines state sovereignty, democracy, and public interests, causing substantial transformations in the character and behavior of the state and the public administration (Farazmand 2012).

As an essential yet controversial issue of our time, globalization thus entails ambiguity in the meaning of political notions such as identity, culture, borders, nation-state, citizenship, class, cosmopolitanism, and global governance.
We propose to add the "globalized individual," the common denominator for all asymmetric globalization actors, as an additional level of analysis.
Typically, globalism has been treated on the national and societal levels, with countries ranked higher or lower on the extent to which they are characterized as globalized.
However, within nations and societies, people vary in the extent to which they adopt a global perspective.

Moreover, even in nondemocratic environments, which Globalization entails ambiguity in the meaning of political notions such as identity, culture, borders, nation-state, citizenship, class, cosmopolitanism, and global governance.
rate low on the extent to which they are globalized, many individuals behave in a highly globalized manner (Khondker 2011).

In the current study, we argue that the ILG scale may serve as a useful tool for examining the psychological processes that shape personal destinies (Bandura 2001) and for elucidating social, political, and national phenomena.
Contemporary globalization processes as internalized by individuals may influence their dispositions, identities, values, and behaviors, as well as feelings toward fellow citizens (Arnett 2002).

ILG is conceptualized to capture the extent to which individuals see themselves as part of a global society, are exposed to globalization processes, and have adopted the global culture of individualism and consumerism.
Globalism here accords with the mentioned attributes, unlike cosmopolitanism, which is essentially related to the individual moral view in respect to the wider world (Delanty 2006).
ILG has been discussed in few previous studies (Adres, Vanhuysse, and Vashdi 2012;Buchan et al. 2011;Sabbagh and Vanhuysse 2014).

We are not aware of any other measure of the individual's level of globalism except for Buchan et al.'s (2009) individual globalization index, which introduces an individual-level measurement of exposure to, and technical participation in, globalization.
We emphasize that the individual's level of globalism is more than just exposure to globalization and that it also manifests perceptions, orientations, and attitudes related to globalization.

This study uses the ILG measure and three conventional experimental procedures to examine the varied ways in which people in four countries resolve the social dilemma of contributions to local public goods between narrow self-interest and collective well-being.
The three experiments represent three main types of contributions to collective action: provision of immediate group public good; obligatory tax contribution; and donation to charity.
Ostrom (2010) emphasizes the importance of experimental methods in the research of the entire "spaghetti plate" of interactions between the variables influencing participation in collective action.
ILG is a manifestation of two of these structural variables: the heterogeneity of citizens and how they are linked to the society and state (Ostrom 2010).

From this perspective, the current research begins to investigate how ILG, over and above a country's level of globalization, may impact such decisions at the individual level, as reflected in contributions to the fundamental resources of public administration for the provision of local public goods.
The collective action approach constitutes the theoretical framework for this study.

Public administration is viewed as a means for allocating decision-making capabilities in order to achieve collective action for the purpose of providing public goods and services (Ostrom and Ostrom 1971).
Ostrom (2010) identifies seven structural variables affecting participation in collective action.
Four variables do not depend on a repeated situation (number of participants, whether benefits are subtractive or fully shared, heterogeneity, and face-toface communication).
Three variables may be affected by repeated situations (information about past actions, link to society/country, enter/exit capability).
Our study asserts that the link to society/ country varies at the individual level and is manifested as ILG.
A key dimension of globalization-and the one that is perhaps most important for the current research-involves culture.
As Tomlinson puts it, "Globalization lies at the heart of modern culture; cultural practices lie at the heart of globalization" (1999, 1).
Culture, as conceived by Tomlinson, refers to all the ordinary practices that contribute to people's "life narratives" (20).
The cultural influence of globalization is multidirectional, creating a cultural fusion.
Intuitively, how globalization might influence individual behavior in relation to contributions to public goods is not difficult to imagine.

Traditionally, social norms and social capital were developed in groups formed by geographic proximity and by the sharing of features such as ethnicity and language (Bernhard, Fehr, and Fischbacher 2006;Habyarimana et al. 2007).
As people internalize global culture, they may be likely to feel less in "partnership" with their fellow citizens (Chong 2000, 48).

That is, their reference group may shift from the nation-state to some broader cross-national grouping based on features other than language, ethnicity, and national boundaries-potentially influencing their willingness to contribute to local public goods (Keser and Van Winden 2000).

We suggest that given the forces of globalization at work in today's world, an individual's approach to globalization is a key dispositional factor differentiating people's link to their society/country even within the same nation and culture.
At the individual level, we argue that globalism can be characterized along four dimensions: (1) self-perception as a world citizen; (2) individualism;
(3) consumerism; and (4) exposure to global mass media, communications, and culture.
These dimensions together compose an individual-level characteristic, ILG.

A higher ILG suggests a shift in the individual's reference group from the nation-state to some supranational grouping, as described earlier, sometimes accompanied by a feeling that one does not "belong" in terms of national affiliation-thus undermining the near-monopolistic position of the nation-state as the central locus of collective identity (Arnett 2002;Castles and Davidson 2000;Meyer et al. 1997;Scholte 2005;Tomlinson 1999).

We further suggest that because of the comprehensive nature of ILG, even less-exposed individuals who rank high on the other dimensions of ILG (i.e., self-perception as a world citizen, individualism, and consumerism) will tend to contribute less to national and local public goods.
It is important to note that we do not ignore the potential role played by the extent to which a country is globalized in the decision to contribute to national public goods.

This research therefore incorporates a variable, country globalization level (CGL), that represents the degree to which a given nation is characterized by the economical, societal, and political markers of globalization.

We presume that in highly globalized countries, individual citizens are likely to have lower levels of nationalistic attitudes and affiliation to the society and state (Norris and Inglehart 2009, 193-98).

However, we argue that CGL is a fixed effect of the location that An individual's approach to globalization is a key dispositional factor diff erentiating people's link to their society/country even within the same nation and culture.
does not influence the relationship between ILG and the contribution to national and local public goods.

In other words, we presume that ILG, which manifests heterogeneity among the population and the link of the individual to the society/country (Ostrom 2010), will be related to the decision to contribute to public goods above and beyond the extent to which the country is globalized.
Thus, we hypothesize the following:
Hypothesis: The higher the ILG, the lower the individual's contribution to local public goods.
Data were obtained from March to May 2013 from a sample of 897 participants in four countries: Australia, Germany, Israel, and Colombia.
All participants took part in three economic decision experiments and filled out a questionnaire (described later).
The settings chosen for the research were selected so as to represent diverse cultures from four continents and variation of levels of globalization.
According to the KOF (2014) overall globalization index, Australia is ranked 19th, Germany 26th, Israel 35th, and Colombia 77th.
The sample consisted of 110 Australian students, 264 German students, 241 Israeli students and 32 nonstudent Israelis, and 250 Colombian students.
Of those, 463 participants were women (52 percent) and 434 were men (48 percent).
The participants ranged in age from 17 to 76 years (M = 24.85,
The German sample completed the experiments in a laboratory facility, while the rest did so in pen-and-paper sessions.
In each country, the project was administered by an experienced local collaborator; no ambiguities in protocol or wording were identified.

The questionnaire and all instructions were written in English and translated into the local language as needed (German in Germany, Spanish in Colombia, and Hebrew in Israel); the translations were validated by the local collaborator.
All participants were assured of full anonymity.

The key elements of the questionnaire were the ILG measure (39 items) and six demographic items (gender, age, native-born or immigrant, birthplace of both parents, household income, and whether the participant was a student).

Willingness to contribute to public goods was captured by three economic decision experiments: a local public goods game, a local tax compliance decision experiment, and a real-life national charitable donation observation.

The experimental settings did not enable communication among the participants (although during the first two experiments, they could see each other in the room), and they were strangers to each other.
Participants received small amounts of monetary compensation according to their decisions in the first two experiments.
The average expected compensation was calculated by each country's collaborator to be the amount needed to buy lunch at the university cafeteria plus the price of a cinema ticket.
The public goods game (PGG) is a group-related experiment in which individuals are asked to make a voluntary contribution to a local public good in a one-shot trial.

The total sum of the privately donated contributions of all session's participants was doubled by the experimenter, and this doubled amount was then distributed evenly among all participants, no matter how much each one contributed.
This distributed doubled amount has all the characteristics of a public good, by being nonrivalrous and by its nonexcludability.
The experiment's design follows Ledyard's (1995) survey of experimental research of public goods.
The optimal outcome for the group members occurs if all participants contribute their entire endowment, while a pure rational choice analysis predicts freeriding (i.e., a contribution of zero).

Experimental evidence suggests that, in fact, the outcome tends to fall somewhere in the middle, with most participants contributing between 40 percent and 60 percent of their endowment (Isaac and Walker 1988;Ledyard 1995).

Because we are interested in the influence of ILG on free-riding behavior, we followed the strategy of Buchan et al. (2009) by defining the dependent variable to be dichotomous, such that the cutoff point distinguishes between "pure" free-riding (zero contribution, coded 0) and any other positive contribution (coded 1).
Procedure.
All participants received an individual endowment of 100 virtual tokens and were informed that each token had a particular monetary value in the local currency .
Participants were then asked to anonymously donate a portion of their endowment (any number of tokens between 0 and 100) to a group project (i.e., a communal pot).

Under the rules of the game, as mentioned earlier, each participant's utility (take-home earnings) is thus the sum of his or her endowment less the amount donated, plus an equal portion of the total sum in the group pot.
This calculation was clearly explained, and calculation examples were provided.
The groups varied in size between 14 and 32 members (most had 19-25 members), and the marginal per capita return (MPCR) varied between 0.06 and 0.14 (M = 0.09).
Calculation of the MPCR is the marginal productivity of the public good (in our game = 2) divided by the group size.
Following Isaac and Walker (1988), with such low MPCRs, we expect no group size effect.
Taxes are a basic contribution to public goods demanded by the government.
Yet it is problematic to accurately measure something that, by its nature, people are reluctant to disclose (i.e., tax evasion; see Alm and Torgler 2011;Andreoni, Erard, and Feinstein 1998).
We followed the designs of previous implementations (Alm, McClelland, and Schulze 1992;Beck and Jung 1989;Cadsby, Maynes, and Trivedi 2006;Torgler 2002;Webley, Robben, and Elffers 1991).
This experiment is an individual economic decision game in which decisions and outcomes are independent for each participant, hence there is likely to be neither group nor group size effect.

As we are interested in the influence of ILG on pure free-riding behavior, we defined a dichotomous dependent variable in the tax compliance experiment such that the decision to disclose the full compensation received and pay the "participation fee" as expected by the "authorities" was coded 1, and any other disclosure was coded 0.
Procedure.
Each participant received a sealed slip on which appeared his or her assigned monetary compensation for participation in the study.
The amounts were randomly assigned, with participants receiving anywhere from $10 to $27.
Participants were not informed of the amounts assigned to others in the session, but they were informed that amounts differed among participants.
Participants were told that to help cover the costs of the research project, they were expected to pay a "participation fee," which would depend on the compensation they received.

This design was followed Cadsby, Maynes, and Trivedi, who showed that "simply telling people that they are required to pay a 'participation fee' analogous to a tax produces remarkably high compliance rates and less sensitivity to changes in economic variables than in the earlier experimental literature using invitation-to-gamble language" (2006,343).
Participants received a table showing different levels of compensation and the participation fee corresponding to each level.
The table represented a progressive tax schedule (higher marginal income incurs a higher marginal tax rate).

Participants were told that they were expected to disclose their accurate compensation but could decide how much of their compensation to disclose, and they would pay the participation fee according to the disclosed compensation.

They were also informed that there was a 5 percent chance they would be audited, and if they were found to have cheated, they would have to pay an extra fee of double the undisclosed participation fee.

This low audit rate (compared with Cadsby, Maynes, and Trivedi's [2006] 25 percent audit rate) and the elimination of institutional uncertainty have been found to attenuate the possible effect of risk aversion on the decision (Alm, Jackson, and McKee 1992).

div.head: Experiment 3: "Real-Life" Donation to a Local NGO

p.s: The third "experiment" was actually a real-life economic behavior observation, resembling a dictator game, intended to identify local charitable giving to a nongovernmental organization (NGO) as a manifestation of contributing voluntarily to a local public good (Carpenter, Connolly, and Meyers 2008;Eckel and Grossman 1996).

Immediately after participating in experiments 1 and 2 and filling in the ILG questionnaire, participants met individually with an assistant experimenter to check out and receive their compensation in the local currency.
Each participant was handed his or her due compensation.

Once the money was in the participant's hands, the experimenter asked the following question: "Do you wish to donate part or all of your payoff to [name of well-known local NGO that helps children at risk]?
You don't have to donate, but it may help people in need."
Each participant's decision was independent of the decisions made by others in the session, hence there is likely to be neither group nor group size effect.
This experiment was not presented as such but as an initiative not related to the research.
The participant discreetly put his or her donation in a big brown envelope, which was opened by the experimenter after the participant left.
We calculated the ratio between the individual amount donated and the total individual compensation received to be "the rate of donation to NGO out of disposable income."
This ratio varied between 0 (zero donation) and 1 (donating the full amount of the compensation).
It should be noted that the total amount donated by all participants was transferred by the experimenter to the NGO.
We controlled for gender, age, and country (using dummy variables with Colombia, which has the lowest country-level globalization score, as the reference group).
For the analyses of experiments 1 and 2, in which the dependent variable is binary, we used binary logistic regression.

For experiment 3, which is a censored model, we employed the QLIM ( qualitative and limited dependent variable model) procedure for a Tobit model with a lower bound (0) (Carpenter, Connolly, and Meyers 2008).
For the extent of cooperative behavior in all three experiments, we transformed experiment 3 results to be binary (donation > 0 coded 1) and ran a Poisson regression.
Table 1 shows the descriptive statistics of the sample in each country.
The distribution (percentage of sample) of ILG (ranging between 1 and 100) in each country is depicted in figure 1.
It should be noted that a comparison of the means for ILG has limited statistical meaning (see the supplementary material available in the online version of this article).
Table 2 presents a comparison between the means of the outcomes of each of the three experiments for each pair of countries (higher mean = more cooperative behavior).

As can be seen in the table, both the mean for tax compliance and the mean contribution in the public goods game were higher in the Colombian sample than in the other three samples, and both were higher in the Israeli sample than in the German and Australian samples.
The mean rate of donation to the local NGO was also higher in the Israeli and Colombian samples than in the German and Australian samples.

The relationships between the country's globalization level and the means of the outcomes of the three experiments are shown in figure 2. As cultural differences are expected to affect behaviors (Cummings et al. 2009), we found that higher CGL was related to lower odds of contributions in the public goods game, lower odds of tax compliance, and lower donations to the local NGO.
The Pearson correlations between all variables in the analysis are presented in table 3.

As can be seen, there was a significant correlation between cooperation in each pair of the three experiments as well as a negative and significant correlation between ILG and behavior in each of the three experiments (higher ILG is related to less cooperation).
Younger age as related to higher ILG and to smaller donations to the local NGO.

A cell (i,j) reports the estimated beta coeffi cient of a relevant dummy variable comparing the two countries in a logistic regression of the public goods game or the tax compliance game and the mean differences between donations to the NGO between country i and country j.
A positive (negative) entry means that the mean of country i (i.e., row entry) is higher (lower) than in country j (column entry).
The results show that controlling for all other variables, a one-year incremental increase in age raised the odds of tax compliance by 2 percent.
Females were 51 percent more likely than males to tax comply.
As for ILG, controlling for all other variables, an incremental increase of 1 percent in ILG reduced the odds of tax compliance by 4 percent, supporting our hypothesis.

div.head: Cooperation in the Public Goods Game
Rate of Donation to Local NGO Out of Disposable Income

p.s: The socioeconomic decision-how much (if at all) to donate-was taken by each participant in a private room and thus was independent of other participants' behavior.
The mean donation rate was 0.12.
The distribution of this experiment's outcomes is shown in figure 3.
As the continuous dependent variable was observed in only a limited range of values, this is a censored model and required the use of a Tobit analysis with a lower bound (0).
The results are shown in table 6.
The parameter Sigma (0.173, p < .001)
represents the improvement of the Tobit model over the ordinary least squares model (SE of the continuous model = 0.179 versus SE of the latent model = 0.173).
Based on the parameter Sigma, we can argue that the division between donations of zero and positive donations improved the goodness of fit of this model.
The model produced a -2 log likelihood of -230.08, and the change in -2LL after adding the ILG variable was significant at p < .01,
indicating that the model including ILG is better than the control model.
The results again support our hypothesis.
Controlling for all other variables, a one-year incremental increase in age increased the odds that a participant donated to the NGO by 1.1 percent.
At the same time, controlling for all other variables, an incremental increase of 1 percent in ILG reduced the odds that a participant donated to the NGO by 0.1 percent.
It should be noted that ILG ranges between 1 and 100, while country dummies are 0 and 1, creating an "optical" diminution of the presented effect of ILG in all three experiments.
Additionally, in a post hoc analysis of each of the three experiments, we tested to see whether CGL moderates the relationship between ILG and cooperation.
These interactions were statistically insignificant, meaning that CGL does not moderate these relationship.

This finding supports our claim that the CGL is a fixed effect and that the relationship between ILG and cooperation in the three experiments does not depend on the extent to which the individual's country of residence is globalized.

div.head: Figure 2 CGL and Mean Contribution to Local Public Goods in the Three Experiments

p.s: An incremental increase of 1 percent in ILG reduced the odds of tax compliance by 4 percent.
The results show that controlling for all other variables, a one-year incremental increase in age increased the odds of cooperation in the public goods game by 4 percent.
Females were 82 percent more likely to cooperate in the public goods game than males.
As for ILG, controlling for all other variables, an incremental increase of 1 percent in ILG reduced the odds of cooperation in the public goods game by 2 percent.
This finding supports our hypothesis.
We tested the group size effect and, as expected (Isaac and Walker 1988), found it to be statistically insignificant.
Our hypothesis is clearly supported by the public goods experiment.
the participants, 3 percent scored 0, 17 percent scored 1, 41 percent scored 2, and 40 percent scored 3.
As this dependent variable is a count variable, we ran a Poisson regression.
As can be seen in table 7, ILG was related to the extent of cooperation, with higher ILG indicative of less overall cooperation.
The results support our hypothesis.

div.head: Overall Cooperative Behavior in the Three Experiments

p.s: To understand whether the behaviors presented in the three studies convey a systematic pattern of cooperative behavior, we tested for overall cooperative behavior in the three experiments.

We ran another analysis in which the dependent variable was the extent to which the individual displayed cooperative behavior (i.e., in how many of the three experiments the participant chose to cooperate).
The scores of the "cooperative" variable range from 0 = no cooperation in any of the experiments to 3 = cooperation in all three experiments.
Among

The current stream of public administration theory enlightens the legitimacy crisis of governments and attempts to bring the citizen back to the center of the discussion (Fung 2015;Nabatchi 2012;Thomas 2013).

In the years during which New Public Management ruled the public administration discourse ("steering" the society), underappreciating the New Public Service method (Denhardt and Denhardt 2015) and leaving the citizen in the shadow (in favor of the customer), it seems that at least some citizens were exposed to forces that shaped their perceptions regarding the state and their duties as a citizen.

From the findings of this research, we see not only that there is variation in the extent to which individual citizens are globalized but also that this variation has an impact on their willingness to contribute to local public goods.
The evidence we gathered supports our basic assumption that within any given society, individuals are likely to vary in their level of globalism.
This added dimension of heterogeneity can help us understand a number of contemporary political and societal processes.

Specifically, it is not only that individuals who live in countries with higher levels of globalization are less likely than citizens of less globalized nations to engage in behaviors that support the collective good.

Rather, we found that individuals who score higher on the globalism scale adopt a systematic behavior pattern in which they are significantly more likely to free-ride in public goods provision processes and significantly less likely to comply with tax laws or donate to local charities.
It should be noted that in our study, these effects of individual globalism were much alike for all four country samples.
These behaviors are thus a manifestation of the relationship between the citizen and society or the state as a bottom-up process, which may imply institutional changes.
Recent research has shown that inclusive social identification with the world community is related to an enhanced likelihood of contribution to a global public good (Buchan et al. 2011).
Our research findings may complement their findings in two main ways.

First, beyond identification with the world community, the ILG scale includes additional values such as individualism and consumerism that enable a broader perspective on globalization at the individual level.

Second, while the results show that higher identification is related to higher willingness to contribute to global public goods, our research shows that higher levels of ILG are related to a lower likelihood of contributing to local public goods.
Thus, our findings hint at a zero-sum game in which the willingness to contribute to a global cause may come at the expense of the willingness to contribute to a local cause.
Future research may want to combine both options in a single study.

Our research provides strong evidence that as people internalize the concept of an almost borderless world, and as they adopt the global culture of consumerism and individualism (Pilkington and Johnson 2003), they become less willing to make the contributions to local public goods that are a manifestation of the individual's commitment to the state and society.

The decline in substantive politics and societal values is perhaps not surprising in an era in which the New Public Management model of governance, which centers around the perception of citizens as "customers," encounters the globalized citizen whose self-perception is based on commitment to some amorphous, supranational grouping governed by the values of consumerism and individualism.
Our findings contribute to the public administration literature in a number of ways.

First, leaning on Denhardt and Denhardt's (2015) notion of a new public service in which the focus is on public service (i.e., "rowing"), civic engagement, and democratic governance, the question regarding who is the citizen who should be served and engaged is critical.
According to Fung (2015), increasing citizen participation may improve the provision of public goods.

However, there are challenges to citizen participation such as opportunistic and unsystematic leadership of participatory innovations and a quite limited tangibility of these participatory innovations (Fung 2015).
These challenges may correspond with the possible transformation in the affiliation and social identity of the more globalized individuals.
Our research takes Denhardt and Denhardt's (2015) ideas and looks at them from another perspective-that is, what characterizes the citizen and not how he or she should be governed or serviced.
We claim that public administrators should understand who citizens are before they can understand what the best way of governance is.

We add the notion of ILG as characterizing citizens and influencing the extent to which they are willing to contribute to local public goods and suggest that ILG may be one such factor that must be taken into consideration when trying to decide which public services should be provided and how to administer them.
Moreover, our study emphasizes that, at least when it comes to ILG, people within the same nation vary, and this affects the extent to which they are willing to contribute to local public goods.

If the willingness to contribute to local public goods is related to the willingness to receive public goods (which must be explored in future studies) the question of the power of public administration for those who are willing to receive less services must be reopened and may create turmoil in our basic public administration theoretical foundations.

If some people contribute less and therefore expect less from Th e decline in substantive politics and societal values is perhaps not surprising in an era in which the New Public Management model of governance, which centers around the perception of citizens as " customers," encounters the globalized citizen.
their public goods provider, we may need to once again face the question of "what public administration should be doing."

Second, in view of the feasibility of exercising the "exit" option by citizens, our findings support concerns about the incapability of contemporary governments to "steer" their populations-that is, to be a central source for the "authoritative allocation of values" within society (Peters and Pierre 1998).

The "public value" discourse relates to "the unacknowledged collision between utilitarian and deontological views of government has created enormous confusion about what the public really wants from the government" (Moore 2014, 472).
Our findings may lead to the question of the meaning of creating "public value" for less connected or highly globalized individuals.
Empirically, this study responds to Perry's (2012) call for research that integrates experimental methods into public administration research.

Finally, at the policy level, ILG may be a useful new explanatory tool for policy-related phenomena such as brain drain and the use of tax havens, in that it exemplifies the citizen's commitment to society/state and, consequently, his or her willingness to participate in collective action.
Future research may want to study the scale of the effect of ILG and the contribution to global public goods vis-à-vis local ones.
ILG also offers a contribution to the globalization literature, which has concentrated on the macro-level impacts of globalization.
These contributions should be seen in light of several theoretical and methodological limitations.
Because of budget constraints, we used a student sample, meaning that the sample may not be representative of the population as a whole.
However, as Alm (2010) points out, there is no reason to believe that the cognitive processes of students differ from those of other people.

Despite the possibility that using a student sample may cause smaller differences among the locations and may also attenuate the rate of donation in the NGO experiment (Eckel and Grossman 1996), the fact that we found support for our hypothesis despite this possible smaller variance in the dependent variable points to the strength of our findings.
Additionally, the fact that the research was conducted in only four countries could raise questions of generalizability and call for future research.
Similarly, future research may want to account for internal ethnical diversity and not only for external country/cultural level diversity.
As our operationalization was aimed at the local level, future research may wish to test similar effects also at the national level.
Finally, it is well recognized that experiments may not fully reflect individuals' behavior in real-world settings.

However, this method offers compensating advantages, specifically, in that the "experimental method permits cumulative empirical and theoretical progress through the rigorous testing of alternative theories, the establishment of causal relationships between key variables, and the replicability of results" (Fehr and Gintis 2007, 44).

To the extent that experimental results are applicable to real life, our research may thus serve as a departure point for future investigations of individual political behavior and may help us achieve a better understanding of developments in the nation-state in the era of globalization.
This study provides empirical evidence that globalization consequences for public administration have two facets.
The first, well-documented facet is the globalized world as a top-down process.
Yet the second facet that is presented in this study is the ILG effect as a bottom-up process.

As public administration encounters growing inconvenience from the New Public Management model, this facet gives rise to the deontological view on government rather than a solely neoliberal utilitarian one.

This delicate perspective may create a dilemma of accountability; is the public administration accountable to the public (who, in turn, feel less committed) or to integration in regional and global processes?

It seems that public administration research and practice should consider the possible evolving institutional consequences of this bottom up globalization effect when considering modification of governance institutions and strategies.

Table 5 presents the binary logistic regression model, in which the outcome variable was regressed against gender, age, country dummies, and ILG.
The results were statistically significant, χ 2 (7) = 169.998
Nagelkerke's pseudo R 2 = 0.231, -2LL = 1068.857.

indicating that the model including ILG is better than the control model.
